title: Microscope
description: This element describes the instrument used to capture the Image. It is primarily a container for manufacturer's model and catalog numbers for the Microscope, LightSource, Detector, Objective and Filters components. The Objective element contains the additional elements LensNA and Magnification. The Filters element can be composed either of separate excitation, emission filters and a dichroic mirror or a single filter set. Within the Image itself, a reference is made to this one Filter element. There may be multiple light sources, detectors, objectives and filters on a microscope. Each of these has their own ID attribute, which can be referred to from Channel. It is understood that the light path configuration can be different for each channel, but cannot be different for each timepoint or each plane of an XYZ stack

title: CouplingLens
description: A lens positioned at connector between this light source coupling element and the microscope body.

Name.description: A user defined name for this component.

ID.description: A unique identifier for this component.

Type.description: The general category to which this lens belongs.

Geometry.description: The geometrical shape of the lens surfaces

Construction.description: Whether or not the lens is simple or composite

Magnification.description: The nominal magnification provided by this lens

AttenuationCoefficient.description: The attenuation coefficient (aka blocking coefficient) is a material property that characterizes the degree of transparency of a lens. The attenuation coefficient is often defined in units of optical density (OD), wherease OD= -log10(T), and T=Transmittance (0?T?1).

RadiusOfCurvature.description: A spherical lens or mirror surface has a center of curvature located either along or decentered from the system local optical axis. The vertex of the lens surface is located on the local optical axis. The distance from the vertex to the center of curvature is the radius of curvature of the surface

FocalDistanceToObject.description: The distance between the front principal plane of the lens and the specimen

FocalDistanceToImage.description: The distance from the rear principal plane to the image

FocalLength.description: The distance from the rear principal plane of the lens and its focal point

MaterialName.description: This records the chemical composition or the nonproprietary trade designation of the glass

GlassCode.description: If available provide the international glass code. This is based on U.S. military standard MIL-G-174, and is a six-digit number specifying the glass according to its refractive index nd at the Fraunhofer d- (or D3-) line, and its Abbe number Vd also taken at that line. The resulting glass code is the value of nd-1 rounded to three digits, followed by Vd rounded to three digits, with all decimal points ignored. For example, BK7 has nd = 1.5168 and Vd = 64.17, giving a six-digit glass code of 517642

RefractiveIndex.description: The refractive index of the material the prism is made of

AbbeNumber.description: The Abbe Number is a measure of the material's dispersion (variation of refractive index versus wavelength), with high values indicating low dispersion

Density.description: The density of the material this lens is made of

Diameter.description: The physical diamter of this lens

SerialNumber.description: The serial number of this component

LotNumber.description: The lot number of this component

ReadNoise.description: Read noise includes thermal noise build-up and clock induced charge. This is generally expressed in e- rms

title: Prism
description: A prism is a block of glass or other transparent material with flat, polished surfaces. A prism can be employed to deflect or deviate a light beam, rotate or invert an image, separate polarization states, or disperse light into its component wavelengths. Prisms can be classified in three general categories: reflecting prisms, polarizing prisms, and refracting or dispersion prisms. Reflecting prisms are useful for redirecting light beams by total internal reflection. Refracting prisms can be employed to bend and separate light into its component colors. Polarizing prisms are birefringent crystals that divide incident non-polarized light into separate components polarized orthogonally to each other. These prisms are employed to produce polarized light for optical instruments such as microscopes and polarimeters. A prism can be viewed as an ensamble of different rigidly mounted mirrors, with each face having a permanent orientation with respect to all the others

Name.description: A user defined name for this component.

ID.description: A unique identifier for this component.

Type.description: The category to which this prism belongs.

Geometry.description: The geometrical shape of this prism

Reflectance.description: The amount of light the prism reflects at a maximum. It is represented as a fraction, as a value from 0.0 to 1.0

PrismAngle.description: The angle between two surfaces of a Prism

AngleOfIncidence.description: The angle of incidence (AOI) is the angle between a beam of light incident on the prism surface and the line perpendicular to the surface at the point of incidence, called the normal.

DeviationAngle.description: A beam passing through an object like a prism is deflected twice: once entering, and again when exiting. The sum of these two deflections is called the deviation angle and is measured with respect to the incident ray

MaterialName.description: This records the chemical composition or the nonproprietary trade designation of the glass

GlassCode.description: If available provide the international glass code. This is based on U.S. military standard MIL-G-174, and is a six-digit number specifying the glass according to its refractive index nd at the Fraunhofer d- (or D3-) line, and its Abbe number Vd also taken at that line. The resulting glass code is the value of nd-1 rounded to three digits, followed by Vd rounded to three digits, with all decimal points ignored. For example, BK7 has nd = 1.5168 and Vd = 64.17, giving a six-digit glass code of 517642

RefractiveIndex.description: The refractive index of the material of which the prism is made

AbbeNumber.description: The Abbe Number is a measure of the material's dispersion (variation of refractive index versus wavelength), with high values indicating low dispersion

Density.description: The density of the material of which the prism is made

title: AdditionalLens
description: A lens poistioned in the light path in the light path for a given channel.

Name.description: A user defined name for this component.

ID.description: A unique identifier for this component.

Type.description: The general category to which this lens belongs.

Geometry.description: The geometrical shape of the lens surfaces

Construction.description: Whether or not the lens is simple or composite

Magnification.description: The nominal magnification provided by this lens

AttenuationCoefficient.description: The attenuation coefficient (aka blocking coefficient) is a material property that characterizes the degree of transparency of a lens. The attenuation coefficient is often defined in units of optical density (OD), wherease OD= -log10(T), and T=Transmittance (0?T?1).

RadiusOfCurvature.description: A spherical lens or mirror surface has a center of curvature located either along or decentered from the system local optical axis. The vertex of the lens surface is located on the local optical axis. The distance from the vertex to the center of curvature is the radius of curvature of the surface

FocalDistanceToObject.description: The distance between the front principal plane of the lens and the specimen

FocalDistanceToImage.description: The distance from the rear principal plane to the image

FocalLength.description: The distance from the rear principal plane of the lens and its focal point

MaterialName.description: This records the chemical composition or the nonproprietary trade designation of the glass

GlassCode.description: If available provide the international glass code. This is based on U.S. military standard MIL-G-174, and is a six-digit number specifying the glass according to its refractive index nd at the Fraunhofer d- (or D3-) line, and its Abbe number Vd also taken at that line. The resulting glass code is the value of nd-1 rounded to three digits, followed by Vd rounded to three digits, with all decimal points ignored. For example, BK7 has nd = 1.5168 and Vd = 64.17, giving a six-digit glass code of 517642

RefractiveIndex.description: The refractive index of the material the prism is made of

AbbeNumber.description: The Abbe Number is a measure of the material's dispersion (variation of refractive index versus wavelength), with high values indicating low dispersion

Density.description: The density of the material this lens is made of

Diameter.description: The physical diamter of this lens

SerialNumber.description: The serial number of this component

LotNumber.description: The lot number of this component

SpecsFile.description: Provide the location of a PDF file with the specifications for the component as provided by the manufacturer.

title: Objective
description: A description of the microscope's objective lens. Required elements include the lens numerical aperture, and the magnification, both of which a floating point (real) numbers. The values are those that are fixed for a particular objective: either because it has been manufactured to this specification or the value has been measured on this particular objective. Correction: This is the type of correction coating applied to this lens. Immersion: This is the types of immersion medium the lens is designed to work with. It is not the same as 'Medium' in ObjectiveRef (a single type) as here Immersion can have compound values like 'Multi'. LensNA: The numerical aperture of the lens (as a float) NominalMagnification: The specified magnification e.g. x10 CalibratedMagnification: The measured magnification e.g. x10.3 WorkingDistance: WorkingDistance of the lens

Name.description: A user defined name for this component.

ID.description: A unique identifier for this component.

Correction.description: The correction applied to the lens.

NominalMagnification.description: The magnification of the lens as specified by the manufacturer - i.e. 60 represents a 60X lens.

CalibratedMagnification.description: The magnification of the lens as measured by a calibration process- i.e. '59.987' for a 60X lens.

LensNA.description: The numerical aperture of the lens expressed as a floating point (real) number. Expected range 0.02 - 1.5.

NominalImmersionMedium.description: The immersion medium the lens is designed for.

Infinity.description: Records whether or not the objective is infinity corrected.

WorkingDistance.description: The working distance of the lens expressed as a floating point (real) number.

Iris.description: Records whether or not the objective was fitted with an Iris.

ObjectiveFieldNumber.description: The maximal diameter of the viewfield allowed by this objective expressed in mm and measured at the intermediate image plane. NB: The field of view is influenced by the magnification and diameter of the ocular (eyepiece) field diaphragm, but also by the limits imposed by the design of the objective.

ParfocalizingDistance.description: The distance between the objective lens mounting plane and the specimen.

BackFocalPlanePosition.description: The position of the back focal plane with respect to the specimen position.

SerialNumber.description: The serial number of this component

LotNumber.description: The lot number of this component

SpecsFile.description: Provide the location of a PDF file with the specifications for the component as provided by the manufacturer.
